Based on my search, I found several academic sources discussing Polish analysis of Reymont's "Chłopi" with focus on symbolism, folklore, and folk traditions. Here are the key findings:

## Academic Analysis of Symbolism in "Chłopi"

The novel is situated "at the border of realism, naturalism and symbolism", representing multiple literary approaches. Academic analysis identifies symbolism in the work through "the presentation of certain situations and characters in such a way that they achieve a timeless, symbolic dimension; for example, the death scene of Boryna in the field, with which his whole life was connected, in this scene Boryna transforms into the symbolic Sower".

## Folklore and Folk Traditions

The novel presents a comprehensive view of Polish folk culture. The work "is not only valuable in terms of plot and aesthetic values, but is also a convincing description of customs prevailing in the village at the beginning of the 20th century. To a large extent, they were related to Catholic holidays, but also to work or folk superstitions".

Village life is organized by "the customary-ritual-liturgical year, which is not identical with the calendar year. It consists of religious holidays, folk customs, customs related to family life, social life, and work in the fields".

## Folkloric Elements and Cultural Preservation

The novel demonstrates how Reymont reaches "the fundamental laws of peasant culture - regulated by the cyclicity of nature, rituality and the rhythm of field work. Here is a community subordinated to nature, living in full harmony with it, governed by eternal laws encoded in almost mythical consciousness".

The work shows the blending of Catholic and pagan traditions, particularly visible during All Souls' Day when "after the finished mass, Kuba goes to the cemetery and leaves bread crumbs for the souls in purgatory".

## Linguistic and Stylistic Analysis

Reymont used "dialectal material from various dialects from the areas around Łowicz, Łódź, Piotrków, Łęczyca up to Wieluń and Częstochowa. He did not introduce one dialect, because the point was not to recreate a specific dialect, but to create some kind of general Polish speech".

The work represents a significant achievement in preserving and analyzing Polish folk culture through literature, earning Reymont the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1924.
